awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Cross Disciplinary Training in Sustainable Chemistry and Chemical Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates site award to Michigan State University, located in East Lansing, MI, supports the training of 8 students for 10 weeks. This program, funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Science Directorate, engages participants in independent research in sustainable chemistry and chemical processes. This program trains participants to be stewards of the environment, leading toward safer laboratories and laboratory practices and reduced volume and toxicity of chemical waste. Participants take part in a variety of professional development opportunities, including journal readings, faculty research presentations and networking dinners, and training in research ethics, basic statistics, laboratory and chemical safety, strategies for applying to graduate school, and communication skills. Incorporation of green chemistry principles can equip and inspire the next generation of chemists to solve the greatest sustainability challenges facing our planet.

The research projects available to participants encompass the theme of sustainable chemistry, including green synthesis, water purification, solar energy conversion and energy storage, environmentally-friendly coating technologies for corrosion control, computational methods for energy-related materials, advanced imaging and spectroscopy, and biocatalysis. This program generally recruits underrepresented students in their junior and senior years. Alongside developing a 'research toolbox', the participants learn how chemistry can be constructed in a sustainable and responsible manner through workshops, lectures, and webinars.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sustainable chemistry is a philosophy that encourages the design of products and processes that minimize the use and generation of hazardous substances. The summer REU program educated 39 students (2019-2022) participants how sustainable practices are impacting research and technology development in chemistry and chemical engineering. The goals of the program were (i) to involve undergraduate students in graduate-level research in sustainable chemistry and engineering, (ii) to provide a positive mentoring experience, (iii) to better prepare undergraduate students for success in graduate school, (iv) to produce a research toolbox (lab safety, notebook, basic statistics, communication, teamwork) for the students, and (v) to significantly enhance their professional development. Undergraduate students entering their sophomore, junior or senior years were recruited through the NSF website (REU Sites: Chemistry), our own program website, established recruiting pipelines (MSU SROP, University of Puerto Rico (UPR) RISE, etc.), and mailings to regional institutions and UPR campuses. These practices produced a highly diverse pool of applicants and student participants. Student participants received 10 weeks of hands-on, interdisciplinary research training in sustainable chemistry and chemical processes. Students  benefited from weekly literature searching and journal reading activities, weekly writing exercises, faculty and industry research discussions, networking dinners, and education in research ethics, basic statistics, laboratory and chemical safety, and strategies for applying to graduate school. At the end of the program, the students presented their results at a university-wide research symposium (Mid-SURE, poster) and a departmental symposium (oral).

Overall, the program continued with a proven recruiting and student selection process that produced a cohort  with an average G.P.A. 3.68 and with 46% of the participants being students from underrepresented groups. The program is having a positive impact both a regionally and nationally with 18 participants coming from Michigan and 21 coming from different states and Puerto Rico in the past period. Finally, the program  included activities to educate and inform the student participants about teamwork/collaboration,  leadership, and career management.

Modified by: Greg M Swain
